Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Undergraduate Research Experiences Through Extragalactic Radio Astronomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests continued support for the highly-successful Undergraduate ALFALFA Team (UAT), which has over the past 8 years provided research-based educational opportunities for 253 students closely collaborating with 25 faculty from a diverse range of universities. Astronomy faculty from 20 institutions, predominantly small colleges in the northeast, carry out several related scientific programs that involve a radio survey of hydrogen in and around nearby galaxies. They obtain new data at several observatories and analyze catalog data obtained at Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico. Undergraduates will be intimately involved in all aspects of the scientific program, including planning and carrying out the observations. They will attend an annual workshop at either Green Bank Observatory or Arecibo Observatory. This program serves as a prime example of the value of scientific collaboration, particularly for faculty and students at isolated schools, and of the importance of research as a component of undergraduate education. This exposure to front-line astronomical research enhances the educational infrastructure and the quality of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) at a large number of schools. The program has an even wider impact through the curriculum and outreach materials they produce and share, and through broadening the participation of groups underrepresented in STEM. Most students who go through the program continue in STEM-related careers.

UAT projects will address major outstanding problems in astronomy and cosmology, such as the number and origin of optically-dark dwarf galaxies, the structure of large-scale filaments, pre-processing of HI gas outside clusters, and star formation in low-metallicity systems. All of these programs are enabled by and make use of the ALFALFA (Arecibo Legacy Fast ALFA) HI survey, as well as new observations. The main components of the program are (1) an annual workshop at either Arecibo Observatory or Green Bank Observatory; (2) observing runs at these and other radio and optical facilities; (3) summer and academic year undergraduate research projects; (4) collaborative research among faculty and students at the member schools. The broader impact also has 4 main components: (1) enhancement of undergraduate education through direct involvement in research; (2) enhancement of educational infrastructure; (3) broad dissemination of curriculum and outreach materials; and (4) broadening participation of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Empowering Research by the Undergraduate ALFALFA Team (UAT) is a collaborative, multi-faceted program of faculty and undergraduate research at a consortium of 23 diverse U.S. institutions. The University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras is one of these institutions. Designed to broaden participation of a diverse group of students and faculty at schools across the country, the UAT advances discovery within the major astronomy legacy ALFALFA (Arecibo Legacy Fast ALFA) project, led by Drs. Riccardo Giovanelli and Martha Haynes at Cornell University, and its follow-up programs while promoting teaching, training, and learning via direct involvement of undergraduates in basic ALFALFA research. Students are engaged in observing at national observatories, analysis of the data acquired by the team and/or complementary data available through public databases, science, and development of follow-up projects.

 

Through this grant, the UAT has developed a successful collaborative model to educate and train students and faculty from a diverse set of institutions as they investigate scientific questions about galaxy evolution, including the influence of a galaxy's environment on its star formation and gas content, the properties of gas-rich, faint galaxies, and the properties of galaxies in the vicinity of a supercluster. At U. Puerto Rico, over the three years of the grant we have worked with 6 undergraduates, 2 faculty and one graduate student through activities such as the UAT workshops, Team observing runs onsite at Arecibo, remote observing runs at Arecibo via internet on campus, undergraduate research projects based on Arecibo science (academic year and summer projects), and presentation of results at national meetings such as the American Astromomical Society.

 

The UAT has extended research opportunities to undergraduates introducing them to a world they may not know exists and broadening their prospective of potential careers, particularly STEM careers. The University of Puerto Rico is a minority serving institution. Our participation of women faculty on the proposal has been 100% and 40% level for the students. Students and faculty have presented their results at national and local meetings. During the time period of the proposal we have 2 alumni, and both are attending graduate school in STEM.

 

The UAT investment in the development of faculty research and education skills at its set of institutions has raised awareness of astronomy on local campuses and in local communities. Our group at UPR have invited students from our astronomy classes to participate in remote Arecibo observing sessions, extending access to a national observatory to a wider audience on campus. We have also shared our expertise and enthusiasm with local colleagues and their students in the classroom. The educational materials, designed to introduce students to the project, are publically available for wider distribution on the UAT and ALFALFA web pages.
